awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multi-proxy sea-level reconstructions and projections in the middle Pacific Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Reconstructions of relative sea-level from geological archives such as coastal sediment offer insight into sea-level changes on a range of geographic (local, regional, and global) and time (years to millennia) scales. These reconstructions can be leveraged to constrain the long-term, pre anthropogenic components of sea-level change, which must be quantified to produce projections of future sea-level rise needed to build resilience in coastal communities. Observational records are too short to perform this task and existing reconstructions spanning the past ~5000 years are primarily located at sites around the North Atlantic Ocean. There is a scarcity of records from the tropical Pacific Ocean, in part due to a lack of sites with suitable coastal sediment. Confounding the lack of data in the tropical Pacific Ocean is the heightened vulnerability of small island nations to the consequences of sea level rise. This project will produce near-continuous reconstructions of relative sea-level change during the past ~5000 years using sediment that was deposited in mangrove swamps in the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM; Chuuk, Pohnpei, Kosrae). Incorporation of the results into a statistical framework will allow regional-scale projections of relative sea level change in FSM during the 21st and 22nd centuries to be developed. These projections will be shared with stakeholders in FSM (e.g., federal and state government agencies and non-governmental organizations) to help plan for future sea level rise. Multi-disciplinary training will also be provided to undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral scientist.

Mangrove swamps have a systematic and quantifiable relationship to tidal elevation, as do micro-organisms such as foraminifera that live on the sediment surface in mangroves and leave a fossil record.  This ecological preference for specific elevations makes mangrove sediment and foraminifera valuable sea-level proxies. As relative sea level rises, mangrove swamps accumulate sediment to preserve their elevation in the tidal frame. Over 100s to 1000s of years, multi-meter sequences of sediment are deposited that can be collected and studied to reconstruct relative sea level. In much of the tropics, however, long-term sea-level fall prohibits the accumulation of sediment. Crucially, long-term tectonic subsidence in FSM has resulted in near-continuous accumulation of mangrove peat over the past ~5000 years. This project will recover sediment cores in FSM and establish a history of sediment accumulation through radiocarbon dating and recognition of pollution and land-use changes of known age in downcore elemental and isotopic profiles. Foraminifera preserved within the buried sediment will be used to estimate the height of former sea-level through quantitative comparison of fossil assemblages with modern analogs. The new reconstructions will be combined with an existing (and updated) database of late Holocene relative sea-level reconstructions to estimate global mean sea-level trends using an existing spatio-temporal model. This model will also facilitate partitioning of the relative sea level signal into its constituent parts to better understand the causes of local, regional, and global trends on short (decadal) and long (multi century) timescales. Using a statistical framework that incorporates multiple sources of uncertainty and accounts for simultaneous and co varying contributions from regional scale processes (e.g., meltwater fingerprints and/or ocean dynamics), this research will produce relative sea-level projections for FSM that will be shared directly with key local stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Micronesia Outcomes

 

Sea-level rise is a concern because of the intense concentrations of population and socio-economic activity at our coasts. This concern is intensified for Small Island Nations, where there is little land above sea level. Tide gauges provide direct observations of historic sea-level trends, but these records are short. To place recent trends in a long-term (multiple centuries and millennia) context, relative sea level (RSL) is reconstructed using proxies preserved in dated sedimentary archives. Most RSL reconstructions come from the North Atlantic Ocean because there is a long-term trend of RSL rise that is well recorded by salt marshes. In contrast, sedimentary records of RSL change are scarce in the tropics because of long-term RSL fall. Consequently, there is a risk that efforts to estimate global mean sea level change during the Common Era could be biased by the spatial availability of datasets. This possibility demands efforts to develop new reconstructions using novel approaches and methods in the tropical Pacific Ocean.

Over the past ~40 years studies have occasionally described the presence of old (several thousand years) mangrove sediment at depth on some islands in the Pacific Ocean (Pohnpei and Kosrae in the Federated States of Micronesia, and in Samoa). This pattern would suggest that the islands experienced sustained RSL rise over the past several thousand years, which is unusual against the regional trend of gradual fall. Subsidence of the islands is the most likely cause of RSL rise in the region. We collected cores of sediment from mangroves on Chuuk, Pohnpei and Kosrae in the Federated States of Micronesia, Upolu Island in Samoa, and American Samoa to reconstruct RSL. Mangrove sites were targeted because the vertical distribution of mangroves is restricted to the upper part of the intertidal zone and therefore has a strong relationship to sea level. The age of depths in the core was established through radiocarbon dating and we used the presence of a biomarker (taraxerol) that is uncommonly abundant in mangrove leaves to establish that the sediment accumulated in a mangrove. Stratigraphic investigations and the presence of pollen from mangrove trees supported our interpretation. This effort was supplemented by compiling and standardizing radiocarbon dates from mangrove sediment on the same islands to establish a sea level database. These results show that Pohnpei and Kosrae experienced anomalous, but sustained RSL rise at ~ 1mm/yr during the past ~4000 years. This inference is supported by lines of evidence including GPS measurements, analysis of tide gauge records, coastal geomorphology and archaeological findings. In contrast, the nearby site of Chuuk did not show evidence of RSL rise. We propose that island-scale subsidence of Pohnpei and Kosrae occurred, although the specific mechanism of subsidence remains elusive. The western end of Upolu island in Samoa appears to be subsiding at up to 1.6 mm/yr over the past ~2000 years at least, likely due to volcanic loading. This result is compatible with the nearby discovery of submerged archaeological material.

There are several implications of these results:

(1)      The new data directly address the scarcity of detailed RSL reconstructions in the tropical Pacific Ocean. However, the addition of the new data does not materially update estimates of how global mean sea level varied during the Common Era, suggesting that previous interpretations were not biased by the spatial distribution of data.

(2)      The migration of people into remote Oceania is documented by finding archaeological evidence of early settlement. Current evidence suggests that Pohnpei and Kosrae were settled unusually late and that a northern and southern route remain isolated from one another. However, this is premised on an assumption of RSL fall. The new RSL reconstructions suggest that evidence of settlement may now be submerged and that the archaeological record is biased young.

(3)      The world heritage site of Nan Madol is comprised islets separated from one another and the mainland by ocean-filled canals. It is believed to have been constructed to separate an elite from the population on the island. The revised RSL curves suggest that the canals may not have been filled with water when constructed.

(4)      In Micronesia and Samoa recent RSL trends measured by tide gauges and satellites show rates of rise that are fast than the long-term average, which highlights the unusual nature of current trends.

(5)      Pohnpei and Kosrae are experiencing ongoing subsidence at a higher rate than previously estimated. This additional mode of RSL rise will persist through the 20th century and should be accounted for by increasing RSL projections for this vulnerable small island nation.
